title: What I noticed on the boards.
body:
There are two paths that a new champ can go through.
1. Be "OP", right as they launch, resulting in the community to yell at the creator of the champion and the balance team. (This includes the ever-present "the balance teams should be fired" complaint.)
2. Be "weak" when they launch, and the new champ being buffed until the community finds out that they have to think of a new way to counter new said champ and call it "OP" demanding that the creator of the champ and the balance team be fired right away.

Both of these pathways result in the new champ being nerfed until they are at a steady win rate, and the community finds something new to complain about. Usually Lee Sin, Zed, and Nidalee.

Just wait until Bard comes out and see if its true. This happens most of the time.

> I personally prefer they go back to what they did with quinn and not worry about every one of their new champions

Uhhh okay, so you want champions to be not overpowered or weak, but buggy as hell (to this day, I might add)?

But buginess and balance aren't completely seperated. For an example, Azir came out and was buggy as hell and sucked ass. He then got bugfixes and became OP.

Same thing with Quinn: If she got bug fixes (AA that didn't cancel in flight, Harrier procing half decently, etc) she too would be OP.

While fixing bugs and balancing are handled separately handled (most likely, I have no clue how Riot does this stuff), bug fixes can make a champion overpowered.

Take Azir for an example. Between his release and him getting gutted, his buffs were:
Base attack damage +4
Base attack speed increased to 0.600 from 0.556
+15 damage to his Q, but -0.1 AP on his W
+20 shield

Everything else was bug fixes and QoL fixes.

Now did the +15 damage and +20 Shield make Azir go from his 38% release win rate to 48% before the nerfs, or was it all the bug fixes?

[Source WR](http://www.leagueofgraphs.com/champions/stats/azir)
[Source Patch](http://leagueoflegends.wikia.com/wiki/Azir/Background)

But you cannot truly balance a champion if they are bugged. It doesn't matter that balance and bug fixes are different departments at Riot, bugged is bugged. Before you balance a champion there has to be no (significant) bugs.

Okay, I have no clue what your point.

Goodbye.

It's not completely irrelevant -- if they're ignoring balance considerations when releasing champions, they might (probably) also ignore bug considerations, since those do affect balance. Azir wasn't good until they fixed most of his bugs.

Though Quinn's case is probably because it was a time when new champs were released at least monthly.
